{'project_name': 'Henan Luoning IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project', 'project_summary': 'Henan Luoning IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project (hereafter referred as “the
project”) is located in Luoning County, Luoyang City, Henan Province, China. The project is to
protect forest from logging to generate GHG emission reductions and contribute to local
sustainable development. Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged
based on a government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The
implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG
emissions.
The project type is “Improved Forest Management: Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF)”. The
project start date is 01/04/2020, and the project area is 9,451.55 ha. The species of this project
are Robinia, Chinese pine, Hard Broad and Cypress.
With the implementation of the project activity, total GHG emission reductions or removals are
about 4,118,556 tCO2e in 30 years the average annual emission reduction is 137,285 tCO2e and
total GHG emission reductions or removals with buffer deduction is about 3,212,467 tCO2e in 30
years, the average annual GHG emission reductions or removals with buffer deduction is 107,082
tCO2e.', 'project_state_province': 'Henan Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 34.37, 'project_longitude': 111.18}

1.13 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Eligibility Criteria
Not applicable since the proposed project activity is not a grouped project.
Leakage Management
According to CDM methodology ACM0002 (which has been applied by the proposed project
activity), leakage emissions are considered as zero for the proposed project.
Commercially Sensitive Information
There is no commercially sensitive information for the project.
Further Information
The proposed project activity is particularly contributing to the improvement of the local
community along the three pillars of the sustainable development:
A - Environmental benefits:
The proposed project activity has positive impacts with respect to the environment. It is offsetting
fossil fuel use and lowering greenhouse gas emissions while helping the country to cope with the
growing demand of energy.
The approved EIA mainly results in showing that the project is not harmful to the environment and
does not report any impact on endangered species.
Besides, thanks to its implementation, the project will contribute to raise the awareness on climate
change among the local community (through the stakeholder meeting) or at a larger scale through
the donation of part of the CER revenue to the Vietnam Environment Protection Fund (for further
details, please see the “economic benefits”).
B - Social benefits
The project is improving the local economy through local employment during both the
construction period (short-term jobs) and the operation (long-term jobs) of the plant. Some of
these jobs require high level of expertize which is contributing to the increase of the local
standard of living. The local knowledge will also increase due to the transfer of technology.
Finally, it has to be highlighted that this project activity is of large scale and that no residential
land is impacted. Thus, no indigenous people have to resettle due to the implementation of the
proposed project activity.
v3.1 7

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
C - Economic benefits
In Viet Nam, all CDM registered projects are especially beneficial for the local community. Indeed,
as per the Vietnamese Circular No: 58/2008/TTLT-BTC-BTN&MT issued by the Ministry of
Natural Resources and Environment and by the Ministry Of Finance, 1.2% of the CER revenue
from the implementation of Renewable Energy Sources projects will be given to the Vietnam
Environment Protection Fund (VEPF). This money will notably be used for supporting the
propagation, disseminate information and improve the public awareness in relation to climate
change and CDM.
The project also contributes directly to the local economy through the payment of local taxes.

The proposed project activity aims to construct and operate a run-of-river hydropower project. Being a run-of-river (rather than accumulation reservoir plant), it offers an environmentally friendly solution to growing energy demand. 4.1 Implementation Status of the Project Activity
The Project’s initial batch of Project instances was planted and monitored during the monitoring

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.8 Description of the Project Activity
The proposed project consists of setting-up 19,440 solar polycrystalline TSM-325PD14 modules
totalling a capacity of 6,318 kWp connected to the 22kV line of Nampower grid through Aussenkehr
substation. This clean energy supply thus implies a substantial reduction in the production of carbon
from the predominantly thermal-based grid mix (dominated by Southern African Power Pool imports),
thereby reducing the associated greenhouse impact upon the atmosphere.
Metering equipment is composed of two bi-directional meters for import/export (Model Landis+Gyr
class 0.2S, main and back-up) located at Nampower’s Aussenkehr sub-station delivery point, as well
as Elster A1700 400/1A class 0.2 within the PV plant premises for control purposes.
The main elements of the solar power plant are:
• 19,440 solar polycrystalline TSM-325PD14 modules (Trina solar, 325Wp @STC);
• 108 inverters Delta RPI M50A of Pnom = 50 kWac each;
• 4 containerized transformers’ stations of 1,600kVA ONAN 0.4/22kV; vector group = Dyn11;
• 22 kV delivery station and underground grid connections;
The solar panels specifications are detailed below:
Based on a Net Energy Yield reference of 2,428 kWh/kWp/year (1st year) for the project site and the
specifications of the solar PV system, net annual output is expected at 15,340 MWh for the first year,
as per PVSyst simulations provided to banks and/or equity financiers in the financial model
(equivalent to 2,428 hours/year or 27.7% load factor), subject to 0.7% annual degradation.
1.9 Project Location
The project is situated in one of the sunniest place in the world, on the banks of the Orange River,
on a 24 ha plot in Aussenkehr in the Karasburg West constituency of the Karas Region, at the
border between Namibia and South Africa.
Its central geo-coordinates are: 28°420’ S - 17°465’E
Solar Power Plant project location and layout

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The project activity will generate emission reductions by avoiding CO emissions from the same 2
amount of electricity generation from the national grid and Southern African Power Pool imports,
which is mainly composed fossil-fuel fired thermal power plants. The project activity is the
installation of a new grid-connected renewable power plant. Therefore, according to AMS-I.D
methodology, the baseline scenario and condition prior to project initiation is that the electricity
delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation
of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources into the grid.
1.11 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
To date, there are no regulations and policies preventing the implementation of the project activity,
which complies with all and any relevant local, regional and national laws, statutes and regulatory
frameworks:
▪ National Energy Policy (2017)1, recently updating the Government of Namibia’s intent,
direction and undertakings regarding the development and future of the Namibian energy
sector
▪ Renewable Energy Feed-In Tariff Rules (2015)2
1 http://www.mme.gov.na/files/publications/fd8_National%20Energy%20Policy%20-%20July%202017.pdf
2 http://www.iea.org/policiesandmeasures/pams/namibia/name-146076-en.php

The project hasn’t sought or received another form of environmental credit, including renewable

1.16.3 Supply Chain (Scope 3) Emissions
According to VCS Standard version 4.4, Sections 3.23.7 through 3.23.9 of the Standard have
been added to require public statements to help avoid double claiming of emissions reductions
and removals in Scope 3 emissions inventories. As per Clarification to VCS program rules and

affected VCS project templates that relate to Scope 3 emissions double claiming until the
effective date of the revised requirements of 1 January 2024.
1.17 Sustainable Development Contributions
1.17.1 Sustainable Development Contributions Activity Description
A summary description of project activities that result in sustainable development (SD)
contributions:
Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to
generate electricity and supply to coal mine to replace the fossil fuel-based electricity
consumed from grid, which has positive impact to climate and also provide jobs.
The Project will contribute to sustainable development in the following ways:
• Displacing part of the grid electricity mainly generated by fossil fuel combustion, thus
reducing the emission of CO and other air pollutants; 94,656 MWh/yr of electricity generated 2
by utilizing CMM will be supplied to the coal mine and to CSPG if there is any electricity surplus,
thus displace equivalent amount of electricity that would be supplied by CCPG dominated by
fossil fuel-fired power plants. Thus, the project will achieve SDG 7 “Ensure Access to Affordable,
Reliable, Sustainable and Modern Energy for All”.
• This project will increase income of local residences and accelerate economy development in
local areas. During the crediting period, direct and indirect employment opportunities will be
generated. Thus, the project will achieve SDG 8 “Promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable
economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all”.

1.5 Project Start Date
The project start date is January 3rd, 2011, which is the date when the small hydropower plant
Ninho de Águia entered into commercial operation. As it was the first plant to operate, that is the
date when the project began generating GHG emission reductions.1
1.6 Project Crediting Period
The project has a 7-year crediting period under the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM),
renewable twice. Under the Verified Carbon Standard, the project has a crediting period of 2
years and 13 days, starting on January 3rd, 2011 and ending on January 15th, 2013 (one day
before the project was registered under the CDM), both days included.
1.7 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals

completed within the relevant validation deadline as set out in Section 3.7 […]”. According to Section 3.7.2 of the

start dates of the small power plants Paiol (which began generating GHG emission reductions on March 23rd, 2010)
and São Gonçalo (which began generating GHG emission reductions on June 8th, 2010), which are part of the

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The project activity is the installation of four new small hydro power plants at river points where
no renewable power plant was operated prior to the implementation of the project activity
(greenfield small hydro power plants).
In the absence of project activity, power energy supplied by SHPs would have been generated by
the operation of the Brazilian National Interconnected System, to which the project activity plant is
connected, and by the addition of new generating plants, as reflected in the combined margin
(CM) calculations.
Therefore, the baseline scenario is identified as the continuation of current situation and future
trends of electric power generation, based on large hydropower and thermal power plants.
1.11 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Right of Use
In respect of a GHG emission reduction or removal, the right of use is the unconditional,
undisputed and unencumbered ability to claim that the relevant project, or jurisdictional program,
will or did generate or cause such reduction or removal.
For the relevant project, the right of use is evidenced by the following dispatches, issued by the
Brazilian National Agency of Electric Energy (Agência Nacional de Energia Elétrica – ANEEL),
which prove the ownership of the power plants and are provided to the VVB:
• SHP Barra da Paciência: Dispatch 1050, of 3/Mar/2011;
• SHP Corrente Grande: Dispatch 251, of 21/Feb/2011;
• SHP Ninho da Águia: Dispatch 4102, of 31/Dec/2010;
• SHP: Várzea Alegre: Dispatch 1456, of 1/Apr/2011.
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
Brazil, where the project activity is located, has neither emissions reduction mandatory programs
nor binding limits on GHG emissions. Therefore, the net GHG emission reductions generated by
the project will not be used for compliance with any emissions trading program or to meet binding
limits on GHG emissions.
1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project neither has nor intends to generate any other form of GHG-related environmental
credit for GHG emission reductions claimed under the VCS program.

Step 4. Common practice analysis  
 
Sub-step 4a. Analyze other activities similar to the proposed project activity:  
 
In line with the EB guidance on the additionality tool, the common practice analysis is carried out on 
similar projects in the same region and taking place in a comparable environment with regards to regulatory 
framework, investment climate, access to technology, access to financing, etc.  
 
In China, the general environment of projects of this  type of wind farm such as the wind resources30, 
on-grid tariff, investment climate  are only similar and comparable in the same province (Autonomous 
Region). On this basis, the common practice region and comparable framework is provincial  and the 
project is  compared to other projects in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.  
 
Taking note of that the proposed project is a large scale project, small scale projects less than 15MW are 
excluded. Using the statistics of installed capacity of wind power in China in 2006, by Professor Shi

(large scale). CDM project activities are not included in this analysis. Only the non -CDM wind farms that

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
1.10.1 Pichincha Province, Cantons Quito, San Miguel de Los Bancos and Pedro Vicente
Maldonado
General information
Project strata 1, 2, 3 are made up of 30+ year old
grasslands near to areas of eco-tourism development
and will constitute buffer habitat to Protected Forests
and private forest reserves. The three strata follow an
altitudinal transect between 2300 meters and 350
meters, ranging from montane cloud forest to coastal
foothills evergreen forest.
Clearing of these lands by early colonists was
exacerbated by the Ecuadorian Agrarian Reform
Laws of the late 1960s which required the
deforestation ―improvement‖ of 50% of a given parcel
for the reception of land title. Since forest clearing Picture 2
soils have lost their original fertility and in many cases
are now compacted and eroded due to grazing pressure and the effects of the non-native grasses
planted on them, principally ‗Pasto Miel‘ (Setaria sphacelata), above 900 meters altitude and
Panicum maximun Jacq, called ‗Saboya‘, in the lower foothills. Picture 2 shows a patch of
‗Kikuyo‘ (Pennisetum clandestinum) found in limited amounts in stratum 1.
Project strata 1-3 are all adjacent to native forest remnants and their specific project areas have
been selected following landowner wishes and zoning of their properties.
Project strata in this area are characterized by high average annual rainfall (2000-4000 mm),
extreme topographical relief and shallow top-soils, and are not sustainable for long-term cattle
ranching. As in the Picture 2 taken at project
participant Grecia Flores´ property, each of these
farms do have select flat areas where soils and
grasses remain in decent condition, however the
majority of these lands are steep and more akin to
Picture 3 also taken at Grecia Flores and Roberto
Nicolalde´s property.
Following this general description of the 3 strata in
Pichincha there are a series of maps with
information on the geological formations, soil types
and erosion potential found in the region. More
specific climate, community and botanical
Picture 3 information then follows by stratum.

output: {'project_name': 'Reforestation with Native Species in the Pachijal and Mira River Watersheds for Carbon Retention', 'project_summary': 'Validation achieved to the CCB Standards Second Edition, Biodiversity Gold Level, on 18 October 2012; expired on 18 October 2017.This project groups 13 private landowners to reforest with native species 346 hectares of degraded grasslands in two different areas of the western slope of the Andes mountains in Ecuador: the Río Pachijal and Río Mira watersheds in Pichincha and Imbabura provinces, respectively. In the broadest sense, the project is divided into 5 strata, 3 in Pichincha with generally more favorable, weather and soil conditions and 2 in Imbabura that are generally more degraded and dry. These disparate environmental realities are also characterized by greater biotic wealth and diversity in strata 1-3 contrasted with species poverty in strata 4-5. As with this disparate ecological reality, Project strata are also disparate in terms of their basic socio-economic realities, with greater prosperity in Pichincha and greater poverty in Imbabura. This distinction is important as the project strata are aligned along two essentially parallel transects that are only some 100 km apart.', 'project_state_province': 'Imbabura and Pichincha Provinces', 'project_country': 'Ecuador', 'project_latitude': 0.062, 'project_longitude': -78.77}

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
Section 2.2 details the ideas and comments made by the stakeholders (Local Stakeholder
Consultation section). The hazards associated with the project's implementation are the main
topic of this section. No risk has been reported overall.
Risks to local population
There are no risks associated with the local population. The impacts on populations are mainly
positive.
Food security of local populations
The progressive degradation of the soil brought on by monocropping in agriculture would restrict
the development of agricultural crops. However, the agroforestry design based on the block,
boundary, and intercropping models will naturally provide nitrogen and carbon to the soils.
Increased crop quality results from increased soil fertility, which increases farmer returns.
Increased incomes
This project will increase farmer’s incomes through the sale of agricultural production, fruits and
timber, as well.
Negative impacts of the project on local populations are negligible.
The grievance redress procedure will be set up as stated in the rules and requirements of the VCS
standard v4.3:
1) The project proponent shall attempt to amicably resolve all grievances and provide a written
response to the grievances in a manner that is culturally appropriate.
2) Any grievances that are not resolved by amicable negotiations shall be referred to mediation by
a neutral third party.
3) Any grievances that are not resolved through mediation shall be referred either to a)
arbitration, to the extent allowed by the laws of the relevant jurisdiction or b) competent courts in
the relevant jurisdiction, without prejudice to a party’s ability to submit the grievance to a
competent supranational adjudicatory body, if any.
If grievances of the landowner occur that could jeopardize the project performance or continuity
thatwould be taken care by the project proponent.

1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The purpose of Guizhou Tongzihe Yangjiayuan Hydropower Project is to utilize local hydro
resources to generate zero greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions electricity for the China
Southern Power Grid (hereafter referred to as CSPG). The Project Developer has obtained
permission to sell electricity to the Guizhou Grid which is an integral part of CSPG that
dominated by fossil-fuel fired power plants. Based on the conditions of the project site, the
project activity has installed and operation of 2 sets of hydro generators with a total capacity of
40MW.
The Project started construction on 01/03/2009 and the two hydro turbines respectively put into
operation on 09/05/2010 and 12/06/2010.
During this monitoring period from 09/05/2010 to 21/11/2011 (both days included), emission
reduction in year 2010(09/05/2010-31/12/2010) is 66,818 tCO2e, and 56,469 tCO2e in
2011(01/01/2011-21/11/2011).

The project activity is in conformation of the sustainable

• Social well-being: The project activity generates clean

adverse impacts of GHG emissions on the people. It also
reduces the energy deficit being faced in the local
region.
• Economic well-being: The project activity generates
employment opportunities as manpower is required for its
installation, operation, maintenance, manufacture, etc.
Such a project activity attracts entrepreneurs to invest
in this technology in the region and thereby resulting in
more local employment, ultimately leading to overall
development. The wind energy developers allow the
landowners and farmers to carry out cultivation on the
land where the WTGs are erected which thus helps in
additional income for the farmers and local community.
Thus, procurement of land has not deprived the erstwhile
landowners of their livelihood and has not resulted in
any resettlement.
• Environmental well-being: The electricity generated shall
replace an equivalent amount of electricity from the
state grid, which is mainly supplied by fossil fuel fired
power plants. Generation of electricity by WTGs does not
result in any type of GHG emissions, leading to a cleaner
environment and also conservation of fossil fuels.
• Technological well-being: The generation of electricity
by the project activity will improve availability of
electricity to the state grid and also it will provide
more opportunities for industries to invest in such

1.12 Project Location
The site is located approximately 4km via road to the northwest of Nkhotakota, Malawi just off the
M18 road between Nkhotakota and Kasungu. The site is approximately 60 hectares with overall
dimensions of ~0.8km long by ~0.74km wide. With reference to below mentioned Image 2 and 3 the

1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The project is a green field solar PV installation, located in the Least Developed Country of
Malawi (UNCTAD6). As per the US AID, the existing operating capacity of ESCOM of 532 MW,
it is heavily dependent on hydro power, this is an issue as the country’s dams frequently face
drought and low water levels (USAID7). While most of the Malawi’s power is hydro-based, efforts
are underway to diversify generation sources with sources such as renewable solar PV and
provide the local communities with energy.
A ‘without project alternative’ would place greater reliance on generating additional power from
fossil fuel sources but also deny the local population potential employment opportunities
associated with the Project. In this respect, the area would therefore continue along a
marginalization path, with high poverty and unemployment levels, poor health facilities, poor
access roads and poor state infrastructure.

The Project Owner has received necessary approvals for development and commissioning for solar
projects from the State agencies and follows the local laws and regulations.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
The Family Forest Impact Foundation (FFIF) is the owner of carbon rights on all project instances.
Evidence is made available to Validation and Verification Bodies (VVBs) in the program archive of
signed landowner agreements.
1.8 Project Start Date
The project start date is marked by the end date of the enrollment period of the first instance, 29
April 2021.
1.9 Project Crediting Period
The crediting period is 20 years, from 29 April 2021 to 28 April 2041.
1.10 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
Throughout this document, the convention is employed that project accounting year refers to the
calendar year at the end of the annual interval, e.g. project year 2021 refers to the annual interval
from January 1 2021 to December 31 2021.
Ex ante projections of emission reductions were developed incorporating the following
assumptions:
• Average stock change in the project scenario = 2.4 t CO2/acre/year
• Average stock change in the baseline scenario = 1.0 t CO2/acre/year
• Difference in baseline and project stock change is due entirely to difference in emissions
and removals. Leakage is calculated from this value (reduction in LTremoved = 1.4 = 2.4 –
1.0 t CO2/acre/year) applying a leakage factor of 10% (no permanent reduction in timber
supply imposed)
• Expansion of the program (new instances included in the grouped project) projected on the
basis of potential acres eligible for enrollment and anticipated enrollment rates by eligible
landowners. No new enrollment projected beyond 2030, though enrollment projections may
be updated over time.
Average annual net emission reductions, before application of the AFOLU non-permanence risk
buffer, generated over the 20-year crediting period are projected to be <300,000 t CO2e, and so
the project does not qualify as a “large project” per VCS rules (>300,000 t CO2e annually).

Project activity involves switch from non-renewable biomass based conventional stoves to

projects excluded as mentioned in Table 1 of section 2.1.3 of VCS standard v4.7 hence
complies to the eligibility criteria of VCS program.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Within the boundaries of the Ceyhan River basin, Ekinözü district of Kahramanmaraş province
south east of Turkey, Kandil Dam and Hydroelectric Power Plant (hereinafter referred as “The
Project”) has been planned to generate clean energy.
The project which was initially developed by General Directorate of State Hydraulic Works in
1966, was planned as a project group. This project group also includes Dağdelen Weir and
HEPP, Sarıgüzel Dam and Hacınınoğlu Weir and Hydro Power Plant along with the Kandil Dam
and Hydroelectric Power Plant project.
The project will be used only for energy generation purpose and has an Energy Generation
License for 49 years obtained from Energy Market Regulatory Authority (EMRA) in 2006. As
understood from the generation licence, the project licence first belonged to “Ere Hidroelektrik
Üretim ve Ticaret A.Ş.” and licence acquisition by Enerjisa Enerji Üretim A.Ş. was realised in
2008.
Within the project, there is Kandil HEPP project activity and a Kandil 1 HEPP project activity. The
Kandil HEPP with an installed capacity of 203.20 MW will produce 498,180 MWh annually. With
the aim of preserving the downstream natural habitat, water with a flow of 5.09 m3/s has been
released from Kandil HEPP. In order to utilise this water flow, Kandil 1 HEPP was planned. The
installed capacity of Kandil 1 HEPP is 4.72 MW and the estimated annual electricity generation is
40,820 MWh. Therefore the total installed capacity is 207.92 MWe and the estimated total
generation is 539,000 MWh/year.
The coordinates of the boundaries of the proposed project activity is 38° 07’ 30’’ and 37° 49’ 30’’
N; 36° 57’ 00’’ and 37° 07’ 30’’.1 E With the implementation of this green-field project, 260,055
tCO2e are estimated to be reduced annually. The total amount of emission reductions are
calculated as 2,600,549 tons over ten years of the first crediting period.
Before the implementation of the project, there was no other hydro power installation at the site.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
 According to UNFCCC sectoral scopes definition for CDM projects, the Project Activity is
included in the Sectoral Scope 1, category “Energy industries (renewable - / non-renewable
sources)”.
 The project is a single green field investment and is not part of a project group or bundle.
1 Environmental Impact Assessment Report, page 5

Shanxi Loufan Afforestation Project (hereafter as “the project”) locates in Loufan County, Taiyuan
City, Shanxi Province of North China. The aim of the project is to increase carbon sequestration
and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees on the barren mountains. The
project was implemented by the project proponent Loufan County Forestry Workstation.
25,001.93 ha (375,029.00 Mu13) of forest is to be planted by direct planting on barren lands in
Loufan County, whose jurisdiction is over 3 towns: Loufan Town, Dujiaoqu Town and Jingyou Town;
5 townships: Miaowan Township, Majiazhuang Township, Gaijiazhuang Township, Miyu Township,
Tianchidian Township; 6 neighborhood committees; and 142 administrative villages. All the project
sites were previously barren lands. There is no natural renewal and afforestation before the project.
The planted trees are native species of Pinus tabuliformis and Prunus dacidiana. The
implementation of the afforestation project will generate GHG emission removals and mitigate
climate change; improve soil and water conservation and forest cover; enhance local biodiversity
by increasing the connectivity of forests and bring income and job opportunities for local
communities and residents.
The project is expected to generate GHG emission removals of 9,838,073 tCO2e in 60 years, with
an average annual GHG emission removal of 163,968 tCO2e.
13 A Chinese metric unit of district, 1ha = 15 Mu.

A.2. Description of the project activity:
>>
Inner Mongolia Tongliao Wind Farm Project Phase IV is located in Kezuo Zhongqi, Tongliao City, Inner
Mongolia Autonomous Region, China. The proposed project will be constructed and operated by Guohua
(Tongliao) Wind Power Co., Ltd. The objective of the proposed project is to utilize the wind power for
generating electricity, which will be sold into the Northeast China Power Grid (NEPG). The total
installed capacity of the proposed project is 49.5MW with 33sets of turbines and a unit capacity of 1,500
kW. The estimated on-grid electricity supply is 108,600 MWh per year.
The proposed project activity will generate greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions by avoiding CO 2
emissions from electricity generation by fossil fuel power plants and will contribute to sustainable
development of the local community and the host country by reducing greenhouse gases (GHG)
emissions of 121,480 tCO e per year. The project will therefore help reduce GHG emissions versus the 2
high-growth, coal-dominated business-as-usual scenario. Furthermore, the project will improve air
quality and local livelihoods, promote sustainable renewable energy industry development.
The baseline scenario, therefore, is the same as the scenario existing prior to the implementation of the
project activity, i.e. generation of electricity by grid connected power plants.
The proposed project clearly fits into the development priority of China. The proposed project will not
only supply renewable electricity to the grid, but also contribute to sustainable development of the local
community, the host country and the world by means of:
• Reduce greenhouse gas emissions in China compared to a business-as-usual scenario;
• Stimulating the growth of the wind power industry in China;
• Creating local employment opportunity during the construction and operation period;
• Reducing the emission of other pollutants resulting from the power generation industry in China

1.13 Project Location
The project's grouped location encompasses the geographic extent of the Cerrado Biome within
the boundaries of Brazil Figure 8. The Keyhole Markup Language (KML) files for this boundary
are attached to this submission.
The Cerrado is the second-largest biome in Brazil, spanning the Brazilian states of Rondônia,
Pará, Tocantins, Maranhão, Piauí, Ceará, Bahia, Minas Gerais, São Paulo, Paraná, Mato Grosso,
and Mato Grosso do Sul. Encompassing an approximate area of 200 million hectares, or 21% of
the national territory, it serves as a transitional biome between the Amazon and the Caatinga.
Characterized by savanna vegetation with small to medium-sized trees, shrubs, and Poaceae
(Grass) 32. The biome plays a crucial role as a water reservoir, and deforestation contributes to
increased drought and erosion. Moreover, the Cerrado is a vital habitat for a diverse range of
plants and animals, and deforestation jeopardizes the survival of many species 29 .
The continuous central portion of the Cerrado Biome, located between the geographic
coordinates of 3° to 25° South latitude and 42° to 60° West longitude, spans the extensive
central region of Brazil. This area includes the states of Maranhão, Piauí, Bahia, Tocantins, Mato
Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, Paraná, São Paulo, Minas Gerais, Goiás, and the Federal District 28.

1.14 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
The use of geospatial monitoring to determine successive transformations in land use represents
a significant advancement in environmental understanding and management. Before the
commencement of a project, a meticulous data collection process is undertaken in the three
years preceding, focusing on removals and emissions critical for establishing a robust baseline.
Data collection on removals is a pivotal component of this procedure, aiming to identify and
record any substantial changes in vegetation cover, deforestation, urbanization, or other
interventions directly shaping the land's morphology. These detailed pieces of information
provide a holistic view of changes in the agriculture environment, crucial for assessing the
impacts and dynamics of land use.
Thus, where the baseline scenario is the same as the conditions existing prior to the project
initiation, there is no need to repeat the description of the scenarios; state that this is the case
and refer the reader to Section 3.4 (Baseline Scenario).

{'project_name': 'Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Dujiangyan City', 'project_summary': 'The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Dujiangyan City within Chengdu City, Sichuan Province of China,
with a total acreage of 12,532 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of
this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice
was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic
matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4)
because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to
water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction than the
continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which
results in not only large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity
by replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which
shortens the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH4
emission can be declined by an average of 48%1. Hence, with the proposed project activity,
an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.47 tCO2e/ha for single-cropping rice is
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 56,045 tCO2e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 560,450 tCO2e during the
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.', 'project_state_province': 'Sichuan Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 30.75, 'project_longitude': 103.43}

the VCS program.

1.1 Summary Description of the project
Yuxian Baiyantuo 49.3 MW Wind Power Project (hereinafter referred to as “the Project”) is
located in Yu County, Zhangjiakou City, Hebei Province, P.R.China. The total installed capacity of
the Project is 49.3MW with 58 sets of turbines and a unit capacity of 850kW. The annual output
of the project is estimated to be 104,713.2 MWh and the electricity will be exported to the North
China Power Grid (NCPG).
The scenario existing prior to the start of the implementation of the project is: the same
electricity output by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation
of NCPG connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources. That is the
same as the baseline scenario.
When the project is operated, the electricity generated will displace part of the electricity from
fossil fuel-fired plants connected to the NCPG, and thus greenhouse gas (GHG) generated by
coal-fired power plants could be reduced. The estimated annual GHG emission reductions in the
first crediting period are 99,501 tCO e/yr, and are 86,587 tCO e/yr during the second crediting 2 2
period.
The project began to construct on 22/12/2009 and was put into commercial operation on
16/12/2010 (i.e. the project starts date). The first crediting period is from 16/12/2010 to
15/12/2020 (10 years, renewable). The project operated normally in the first crediting period.
The project is applying for the crediting period renewal and the second crediting period is
expected from 16/12/2020 to 15/12/2030 (10 years).
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project falls in the sectoral scope 1: energy industries (renewable-/non-renewable
sources).
Project type: Renewable (wind) power project
The project is not a grouped project.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The project is a wind power project, which reduces CO by replacing electricity from fossil fuel 2
power plants. This complies with the scope of VCS program.
1.4 Project Design
This project is a single project. It is not designed to include multiple project activity instances,
or as a grouped project.

{'project_name': 'Ground-Truth Australian Orchards', 'project_summary': 'Regenerative farming practices have been proposed as a means to reduce the climate impact and carbon footprint of agriculture by, inter alia, enhancing the ability of agricultural soils to store carbon, buffering food production systems from environmental changes, improving water and nutrient use efficiency, and removing CO2 from the atmosphere. 
For this project, which encompasses regenarative orchards in Australia, GHG reductions and removals will be achieved by the implementation of a combination of the following practice changes: 
•	Reduce the intensity of agricultural practices, specifically reducing the use of synthetic fertilisers by incorporating organic amendments, and reducing the use of chemical pesticides via improved integrated pest management 
•	Cover cropping, including promoting inter-row biomass generation and the establishment of multi-species cover crops
•	Establishment of new permanent tree crops and associated canopy growth
•	Promote specific regeneration of soil and the increase of soil organic carbon (SOC)
•	Reduce water consumption and energy use through improved irrigation management 
•	Promote carbon sequestration in the above ground biomass
•	Improved crop residue management by re-incorporating prunings and crop waste into the soil
The undertaking of this project will support a number of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals in the project area, local communities, surrounding environments, and in the supply chain. The project will contribute towards SDG 2: Zero Hunger, SDG 3: Good Health and Wellbeing, SDG 6: Clean Water and Sanitation, SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production, SDG 13: Climate Action, SDG 14: Life Below Water, and SDG 15: Life on Land.', 'project_state_province': 'Australia', 'project_country': 'Australia', 'project_latitude': -24.78, 'project_longitude': 134.75}
